abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We develop linear mixed models (LMMs) and functional linear mixed models (FLMMs) for gene‐based tests of association between a quantitative trait and genetic variants on pedigrees. The effects of a major gene are modeled as a fixed effect, the contributions of polygenes are modeled as a random effect, and the correlations of pedigree members are modeled via inbreeding/kinship coefficients. <jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="graphic/gepi22177-math-0001.png" xlink:title="urn:x-wiley:07410395:media:gepi22177:gepi22177-math-0001" />‐statistics and 
<jats:italic>χ</jats:italic>
<jats:sup>2</jats:sup> likelihood ratio test (LRT) statistics based on the LMMs and FLMMs are constructed to test for association. We show empirically that the <jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="graphic/gepi22177-math-0002.png" xlink:title="urn:x-wiley:07410395:media:gepi22177:gepi22177-math-0002" />‐distributed statistics provide a good control of the type I error rate. The <jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="graphic/gepi22177-math-0003.png" xlink:title="urn:x-wiley:07410395:media:gepi22177:gepi22177-math-0003" />‐test statistics of the LMMs have similar or higher power than the FLMMs, kernel‐based famSKAT (family‐based sequence kernel association test), and burden test famBT (family‐based burden test). The <jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="graphic/gepi22177-math-0004.png" xlink:title="urn:x-wiley:07410395:media:gepi22177:gepi22177-math-0004" />‐statistics of the FLMMs perform well when analyzing a combination of rare and common variants. For small samples, the LRT statistics of the FLMMs control the type I error rate well at the nominal levels <jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="graphic/gepi22177-math-0005.png" xlink:title="urn:x-wiley:07410395:media:gepi22177:gepi22177-math-0005" /> and <jats:inline-graphic xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href="graphic/gepi22177-math-0006.png" xlink:title="urn:x-wiley:07410395:media:gepi22177:gepi22177-math-0006" />. For moderate/large samples, the LRT statistics of the FLMMs control the type I error rates well. The LRT statistics of the LMMs can lead to inflated type I error rates. The proposed models are useful in whole genome and whole exome association studies of complex traits.</jats:p>
